stages.name: Launch
stages.text: OSIRIS-REx launched from Cape Canaveral on an Atlas V to rendezvous with near-Earth asteroid Bennu, survey it in detail, collect a sample, and return it to Earth for laboratory study.

stages.name: Earth gravity assist
stages.text: A close Earth flyby provided a gravity assist to bend the spacecraft’s trajectory onto a path toward Bennu.

stages.name: Arrival at Bennu
stages.text: OSIRIS-REx arrived at asteroid Bennu and began detailed survey and mapping to select a safe and scientifically valuable sampling site.

stages.name: Sample collection (TAG)
stages.text: The spacecraft performed a Touch-And-Go (TAG) maneuver to collect regolith using a burst of nitrogen gas, successfully capturing material from Bennu’s surface.

stages.name: Depart Bennu
stages.text: After securing the sample in its return capsule, OSIRIS-REx departed Bennu and began its cruise back toward Earth.

stages.name: Sample return to Earth
stages.text: The sample return capsule was delivered to Earth and recovered in Utah, completing NASA’s first U.S. asteroid sample return; the spacecraft continued on an extended mission toward asteroid Apophis (OSIRIS-APEX).

stages.name: Apophis encounter (planned)
stages.text: Extended mission: the spacecraft (renamed OSIRIS-APEX) is planned to encounter and study asteroid Apophis after its close approach to Earth in 2029.
